chunk_summary: Differential diagnosis of typhoid and enteric fever emphasizes ruling out co-infections like malaria, dengue, scrub typhus, and tuberculosis, especially in atypical cases or failure to respond to therapy in endemic regions like India.
learning_objectives: Understand the differential diagnosis process for typhoid and enteric fever in pediatric cases.
Identify key co-infections such as malaria, dengue, scrub typhus, and leptospirosis that mimic enteric fever.
Recognize clinical signs like eschar, conjunctival suffusion, or jaundice to differentiate conditions.
Learn when to reconsider diagnosis and evaluate for complications or chronic conditions.
key_facts: Enteric fever is a common cause of prolonged pediatric fever in India.
Malaria and dengue can coexist with enteric fever and present with hepatosplenomegaly.
Scrub typhus mimics typhoid; look for eschar and use region-specific tests.
Leptospirosis is associated with conjunctival suffusion, myalgias, and flood-water exposure.
Persistent fever beyond two weeks may indicate tuberculosis, endocarditis, or malignancy.
Failure to improve on anti-typhoidal therapy warrants diagnostic reconsideration.
Evidence-based supportive care measures are essential
reference_quote: Malaria and dengue are high-priority exclusions in many regions; both can present with fever, headache, and hepatosplenomegaly, and both may coexist with enteric fever. (StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf)
